topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Brendan Foody and Mercor, highlighting its record-breaking growth, fundraising, and what the episode will cover (evals, AI training labor, future of work).

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for WorkOS and Jira Product Discovery.

topics.title: The era of evals explained
topics.summary: Brendan frames evals as the PRD for AI models: researchers iterate on eval sets, and RL makes progress fast once success is measurable. The big blocker to automating workflows is defining and measuring success.

topics.title: How enterprises should approach evals
topics.summary: Brendan advises companies to build systematic tests for how AI automates their value chain (e.g., architecture deliverables). Measuring success is the prerequisite to deploying AI broadly inside a business.

topics.title: Evals as marketing and sales collateral
topics.summary: They discuss the idea that evals are not only internal requirements but also how labs and app companies demonstrate capability. The shift is from academic benchmarks to practical, domain-specific evals customers care about.

topics.title: AI training market landscape and Mercor origin
topics.summary: Brendan explains Mercor’s beginnings as an AI-driven hiring automation product, then the pivot after seeing labs’ need for vetted experts. He describes the transition from low-skill crowdsourcing to high-skill sourcing and assessment.

topics.title: Why expert eval labor is so valuable
topics.summary: Brendan argues labs’ main bottleneck is measuring success (evals/verifiers) across domains, and top companies will pay heavily to improve capabilities. Mercor sits at this bottleneck by supplying expert professionals.

topics.title: What experts do day-to-day: rubrics and verifiers
topics.summary: Concrete example: lawyers create rubrics for contract redlining to score model outputs and provide training signals. They connect evals to RL environments and clarify that it’s the same underlying artifact used for testing and training.

topics.title: From SFT and RLHF to AI feedback
topics.summary: Brendan outlines historical data types (SFT and RLHF) and the move toward reinforcement learning from AI feedback, where humans define success criteria and AI scales evaluation. This is more data-efficient and scalable for labs.

topics.title: How long humans will be needed for evals
topics.summary: They debate timelines to superintelligence; Brendan believes models still fail at many basics and will need evals for tool use and long-horizon tasks for a long time. He frames this as a major new category of work, not just displacement.

topics.title: Skills and jobs that remain valuable
topics.summary: Brendan recommends focusing on elastic-demand domains (like software) where productivity gains increase output, and on learning to leverage AI tools directly. He argues assessments should encourage tool use (build something in an hour) rather than ban it.

topics.title: Unified labor markets and AI-driven hiring
topics.summary: Brendan explains Mercor’s original thesis: labor markets are disaggregated due to manual matching, and AI can enable a global unified market. Lenny notes AI increases application volume, forcing smarter filtering and selection.

topics.title: Post-training experts, scale, and competition
topics.summary: They clarify Mercor’s work is largely post-training (reasoning and prioritization), discuss the scale (tens of thousands active), and contrast high-skill expert sourcing with older low-skill crowdsourcing incumbents. Brendan also compares to expert networks like AlphaSights and GLG.

topics.title: Creative vs technical experts and talent economics
topics.summary: Brendan describes demand across both professional and creative domains (e.g., comedy writers, screenwriters), turnaround speed, and the ‘top 10% drive most impact’ dynamic. They cover engagement models (often part-time) and pay rates (median ~$95/hr up to $500/hr).

topics.title: Why some models excel: reward design and evals
topics.summary: Lenny asks why Anthropic is strong at coding; Brendan points to reinforcement learning, careful reward definition, and preventing reward hacking—returning to the mantra that model quality tracks eval quality.

topics.title: How Mercor achieved hypergrowth
topics.summary: Brendan shares operating principles: follow leading indicators in fast-moving markets and obsess over customer experience (minimal sales/marketing, heavy product focus). He recounts early signals (xAI meeting, incumbent failures) and lessons on finding ‘easy to sell’ pull vs forcing PMF.

topics.title: Company values and operating tenets (partial)
topics.summary: Brendan begins outlining Mercor’s internal values, starting with a ‘can-do attitude’ and setting extremely ambitious goals that shape execution. The segment cuts off mid-thought as he starts giving examples.
